title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker trying to determine when asking people to compare the temperatures of a metal hard drive and a book?

options.label: A
options.text: Which object is heavier

options.label: B
options.text: Which object is warmer or colder

options.label: C
options.text: Which object is more expensive

options.label: D
options.text: Which object is more useful

multiple-choice.question: According to the experiment, what is the temperature of both the book and the hard drive?
Why does the metal hard drive feel colder than the book, even though they are at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Because metal is always colder than other materials

options.label: B
options.text: Because the book has more knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: Because metal conducts heat away from the hand faster

options.label: D
options.text: Because the hard drive is more dense

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that explains why some materials feel warmer or colder than others, even if they are at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Thermoconductivity

options.label: B
options.text: Thermal expansion

options.label: C
options.text: Heat transfer

options.label: D
options.text: Convection

multiple-choice.question: In the experiment with the aluminium and plastic blocks, what happens to the ice cube on each block?

options.label: A
options.text: The ice cube on the aluminium block stays solid, while the ice cube on the plastic block melts

options.label: B
options.text: The ice cube on the aluminium block melts, while the ice cube on the plastic block stays solid

options.label: C
options.text: The ice cube on the aluminium block melts faster than the ice cube on the plastic block

options.label: D
options.text: The ice cube on the plastic block melts faster than the ice cube on the aluminium block

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why the aluminium block melts the ice cube faster than the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: Because aluminium is a better insulator

options.label: B
options.text: Because aluminium is a worse conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: Because aluminium conducts heat to the ice cube faster

options.label: D
options.text: Because plastic is a better conductor of heat

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "you don't actually feel temperature" when you touch something?

options.label: A
options.text: That temperature is just an illusion

options.label: B
options.text: That our sense of touch is unreliable

options.label: C
options.text: That we feel the rate at which heat is conducted, not the actual temperature

options.label: D
options.text: That temperature is only a measure of heat transfer

multiple-choice.question: Why is it more comfortable to stand on a bath mat than on a towel after taking a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer than the towel

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat is softer than the towel

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from the body

options.label: D
options.text: Because the towel is more slippery than the bath mat

multiple-choice.question: How does the concept of thermoconductivity apply to everyday life?

options.label: A
options.text: It only applies to scientific experiments

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us understand why some materials feel warmer or colder than others

options.label: C
options.text: It explains why some materials are better insulators than others

options.label: D
options.text: It is only relevant to engineers and physicists

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker is trying to convey through the experiments and explanations?

options.label: A
options.text: That temperature is the only factor that determines how warm or cold something feels

options.label: B
options.text: That our sense of touch is unreliable when it comes to temperature

options.label: C
options.text: That the rate at which heat is conducted is what we actually feel when we touch something

options.label: D
options.text: That some materials are always warmer or colder than others

title: How the mantis shrimp can break glass

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the mantis shrimp's "smasher"?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture prey using its speed

options.label: B
options.text: To defend against predators by intimidation

options.label: C
options.text: To break open shells and access food

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other mantis shrimps through sound

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the shape that plays a crucial role in the mantis shrimp's punch?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperbolic paraboloid

options.label: B
options.text: Elliptical orbit

options.label: C
options.text: Triangular prism

options.label: D
options.text: Spherical cap

multiple-choice.question: According to Dr. Seymour, what is necessary for the mantis shrimp to achieve its incredibly fast punch?

options.label: A
options.text: Muscle movement alone is sufficient

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of muscle movement and stored energy is required

options.label: C
options.text: A specialized nervous system is necessary for speed

options.label: D
options.text: A unique circulatory system is essential for power

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organic polymer that makes up the mantis shrimp's smasher, providing it with exceptional strength?

options.label: A
options.text: Chitin

options.label: B
options.text: Keratin

options.label: C
options.text: Cellulose

options.label: D
options.text: Protein

multiple-choice.question: How do the fibers in the mantis shrimp's smasher contribute to its remarkable strength?

options.label: A
options.text: They are oriented in two principle directions, like plywood

options.label: B
options.text: They are oriented in a helix, providing strength in multiple directions

options.label: C
options.text: They are randomly oriented, reducing overall strength

options.label: D
options.text: They are absent, making the smasher brittle

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using a synchrotron to analyze the mantis shrimp's smasher?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine its density and composition

options.label: B
options.text: To understand its material makeup and crystal structure

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze its internal structure and geometry

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the composition of the mantis shrimp's smasher?

options.label: A
options.text: It is uniform throughout, with no variations

options.label: B
options.text: It changes composition and strength at different locations, adapting to needs

options.label: C
options.text: It is made of a single material, with no composites

options.label: D
options.text: It is brittle and prone to breakage

multiple-choice.question: How does the mantis shrimp's smasher distribute the force of impact?

options.label: A
options.text: By concentrating it at the point of impact, increasing pressure

options.label: B
options.text: By distributing it evenly throughout the structure, reducing stress

options.label: C
options.text: By transitioning smoothly from a hard impact surface to a softer internal structure

options.label: D
options.text: By absorbing it, reducing the impact

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the mantis shrimp's variable composite structure?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides uniform strength throughout, with no weaknesses

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for variation in material makeup and strength orientation, adapting to needs

options.label: C
options.text: It is less expensive to produce, with reduced material costs

options.label: D
options.text: It is more prone to damage, with increased fragility

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of the mantis shrimp's vision?

options.label: A
options.text: It can see in low light conditions, with enhanced sensitivity

options.label: B
options.text: It can see circularly polarized light, with increased perception

options.label: C
options.text: It can see in multiple directions simultaneously, with wide field of view

options.label: D
options.text: It is colorblind, with reduced visual acuity

title: Making a TED-Ed Lesson: Bringing a pop-up book to life

multiple-choice.question: What inspired the creation of a pop-up book to explain Earth's tectonic plates?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the movement easily with drawings

options.label: B
options.text: To depict gigantic sliding slabs of rock using a tangible object

options.label: C
options.text: To create a stop-motion animation

options.label: D
options.text: To illustrate the lesson simply by playing with shapes and colors

multiple-choice.question: What basic paper tools are necessary for making a pop-up book?

options.label: A
options.text: Scissors, glue, and a ruler

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Scissors, glue, and a bone folder

options.label: D
options.text: Scissors, an X-Acto knife, and a ruler

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Accordion fold and V-fold

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To test the durability of the pop-up book

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: C
options.text: By using wedges to support the pages

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: To create a realistic effect

options.label: B
options.text: To achieve the desired effect

options.label: C
options.text: To make the animation more complex

options.label: D
options.text: To add visual interest and creativity to the animation

options.text: Start plotting the ins and outs of your pop-up book

options.label: B
options.text: Create a mock-up spread

options.label: C
options.text: Test the prototype

options.label: D
options.text: Develop a visual style and choose a storyline

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a stop-motion animation

options.label: C
options.text: By illustrating a lesson simply by playing with shapes and colors

options.label: D
options.text: By designing an interactive display for a museum or exhibit

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using a pop-up book to explain a complex concept like Earth's tectonic plates?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can You Solve This?

options.label: C
options.text: Multiplying by 2

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to get at the truth and avoid fooling oneself

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: By relying solely on intuition

options.label: A
options.text: Numbers in descending order

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Linear cause and effect

options.label: D
options.text: Random chance

options.label: A
options.text: Negative feedback

options.label: B
options.text: Positive feedback

options.label: C
options.text: Neutral feedback

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.text: The probability of the car being behind the initial door is higher than the probability of it being behind the other door.

options.text: The probability of the car being behind the initial door is higher than the probability of it being behind the other door.

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the amount of light entering the eye

multiple-choice.question: A designer wants to create an optical illusion that tricks the brain into seeing a 3D shape. Which technique would be most effective?

options.label: A
options.text: Using shading patterns to create a 3D shape

options.label: B
options.text: Using colors to create a 3D shape

options.label: C
options.text: Using shapes to create a 3D shape

options.label: D
options.text: Using motion to create a 3D shape

multiple-choice.question: Why is the brain able to recognize faces quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain has specifically evolved areas to recognize faces

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is able to recognize faces because of the eyes and mouth

options.label: C
options.text: The brain relies solely on prior experiences to recognize faces

options.label: D
options.text: The brain uses a combination of visual and auditory information to recognize faces

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Optical illusions are a result of the brain's inability to process visual information accurately

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is lazy and takes shortcuts when processing visual information

options.label: C
options.text: The brain uses assumptions and tricks to construct a 3D world

options.label: D
options.text: The brain relies solely on prior experiences to interpret visual information

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the visual cortex in processing visual information?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect colors

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize shapes

options.label: C
options.text: To interpret visual information based on assumptions about lighting and shading

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the amount of light entering the eye

multiple-choice.question: Why are edges important in visual perception?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they help the brain recognize shapes

options.label: B
options.text: Because they help the brain detect colors

options.label: C
options.text: Because they help the brain interpret visual information and detect potential threats or objects

options.label: D
options.text: Because they help the brain regulate the amount of light entering the eye

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is comprised of coral reefs, which are home to over a quarter of the 27,000 known fish species?

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 1%

multiple-choice.question: How do most coral reef fish species reproduce?

options.label: A
options.text: They lay eggs on the reef that hatch into larvae.

options.label: B
options.text: They give birth to live young.

options.label: C
options.text: They release sperm and eggs into the water column, which then fertilize and drift with the currents.

options.label: D
options.text: They mate on land and then return to the water.

multiple-choice.question: What is likely to happen to a coral reef fish larva if it is unable to find a suitable adult habitat?

options.label: A
options.text: It will continue to grow and thrive in the open ocean.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be swept away by currents and never find a home.

options.label: C
options.text: It will adapt to a new environment and change its species.

options.label: D
options.text: It will ride the currents until it finds a suitable habitat or dies.

multiple-choice.question: What sensory systems do coral reef fish larvae use to navigate through the water column?

options.label: A
options.text: Only sound

options.label: B
options.text: Only smell

options.label: C
options.text: A complex suite of sensory systems, including sound and smell

options.label: D
options.text: Only visual cues

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition of coral reef fish larvae when they first emerge from their eggs?

options.label: A
options.text: They are fully formed and ready to settle on a reef.

options.label: B
options.text: They are tiny and vulnerable, and may not even have gills yet.

options.label: C
options.text: They are swept away by currents and never found again.

options.label: D
options.text: They immediately begin swimming towards a reef.

multiple-choice.question: How has our understanding of coral reef fish larvae changed with recent research findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Previously, larvae were thought to be strong swimmers, but current research shows they are passive drifters.

options.label: B
options.text: Previously, larvae were thought to be passive drifters, but current research shows they are capable of taking an active role in their fate.

options.label: C
options.text: Previously, larvae were thought to rely solely on sound for navigation, but current research shows they use a complex suite of sensory systems.

options.label: D
options.text: Previously, larvae were thought to settle on a reef immediately, but current research shows they have a bungee system.

multiple-choice.question: What allows coral reef fish larvae to distinguish between different environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound waves

options.label: B
options.text: Visual cues

options.label: C
options.text: Odor

options.label: D
options.text: Temperature changes

multiple-choice.question: What type of experiment would be most effective in testing the hypothesis that coral reef fish larvae can navigate using a complex suite of sensory systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Release larvae into a tank with different water masses and observe their movement.

options.label: B
options.text: Play different sounds and observe the larvae's response.

options.label: C
options.text: Create a maze with different environments and observe the larvae's navigation.

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of the above experiments.

multiple-choice.question: Why are coral reefs important habitats for fish species?

options.label: A
options.text: Coral reefs are a minor habitat for fish species, supporting only a few thousand species.

options.label: B
options.text: Coral reefs are a critical habitat for fish species, supporting over a quarter of all known species.

options.label: C
options.text: Coral reefs are an irrelevant habitat for fish species, as most species live in the open ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: Coral reefs are a declining habitat for fish species, and most species are adapting to new environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is one area where further research is needed to understand the life cycle of coral reef fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The reproductive habits of adult fish.

options.label: B
options.text: The geographic movements of individual larvae.

options.label: C
options.text: The sensory systems used by larvae for navigation.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of climate change on coral reefs.
